I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will complement Kazakhstan’s 
efforts  to  promote  sustainable  economic  development  through  improved  use  of  digital 
technologies, in line with the government’s Digital Kazakhstan program.1 The TA will support the 
following activities: (i) mapping of existing opportunities and obstacles to adopting selected digital 
technology solutions, (ii) developing the capacity of local stakeholders to apply selected high-level 
technologies, and (iii) conducting feasibility studies in the areas of smart -city, grid, metering for 
possible future Asian Development Bank (ADB) investment projects. 
 
2.  By promoting high-level technologies, the TA project is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030.2 
The TA project is also fully aligned with ADB’s country partnership strategy for Kazakhstan, 2017–
2021, which highlights ADB’s role in supporting the social impact of technology solutions in areas 
such as municipal services, e-commerce, agribusiness, green economy, and finance.3 
 
3.  The TA project is included in ADB’s country operations business plan for Kazakhstan, 
2020–2022. 4  Its  implementation  is  aligned  with  ADB’s  focus  on  supporting  economic 
diversification through technological change and capacity development of developing member 
country (DMC) stakeholders.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Kazakhstan is seeking to transform its economy and improve people’s living standards by 
promoting the use of information and communication technology (ICT) as outlined in the Digital 
Kazakhstan state program (footnote 1). The Ministry of Digital Development, Innovations and 
Aerospace  Industry  (MDDIAI)  manages  the  country’s  digitalization  agenda.6 However,  the 
MDDIAI  makes  limited  information  available  to  development  partners  and  other  external 
stakeholders on the country’s progress in digitalizing. What information it does make available is 
scattered and often provided with a substantial time lag, limiting its usefulness for development 
partners in supporting initiatives that incorporate high-level technologies. 
 
5.  The goal of Digital Kazakhstan is to use ICT to accelerate economic growth and raise 
living standards. The program is running over 5 years, from 2018 to 2022. The central government 
has allocated T141 billion (about $400 million) for the project; however, completing most of 
program’s components will require about $500 million in additional private and quasi-government 
funding. While the government has made an effort to highlight the opportunities that Digital 
Kazakhstan will create, it has provided few details on the program’s incentive systems and 
adaptation mechanisms and tends to downplay challenges facing Kazakhstan in adopting high-
 
1  Government of Kazakhstan. 2017. Digital Kazakhstan. Astana. This state program is designed to introduce digital 
technology solutions to a wide spectrum of sectors and activities. 
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. The term “high-level technologies” is defined as new and advanced technologies or innovative solutions that 
improve efficiency, productivity, quality, and/or functionality. Additional discussion of the term is available in ADB. 
2018. High-Level Technology: Guidance Note on Procurement. Manila. 
3  ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Kazakhstan, 2017–2021—Promoting Economic Diversification, Inclusive 
Development and Sustainable Growth. Manila. 
4  ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: Kazakhstan, 2020–2022. Manila. 
5  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 1 August 2019. 
6  To do this, MDDIAI uses “Bitrix24,” a web-based project management platform with time tracking, workflow 
automation tools, Gantt charts, group chats, video conferencing and other document management and task 
collaboration tools. The information is used internally by decision-makers in the MDDIAI, while reports produced for 
external parties contain limited information.

2 
level technologies. ADB experience in supporting DMCs with digital technologies shows that 
asymmetric information, externalities, and spillover effects often tend to preclude stakeholders 
from championing digital technology solutions. As a result, DMCs often fail to identify and adopt 
emerging high-level technologies. 
 
6.  Citizens, the government, and businesses require ICT skills and knowledge to exploit 
digital technologies. One goal of Digital Kazakhstan is to foster entrepreneurship and create a 
culture of innovation in Kazakhstan. A program priority was the formation of Astana Hub, a 
technology  incubator  launched  in  November  2018  that  features  accelerator  for  high-level 
technology start-ups, co-working spaces, and office space for tech firms. One important role of 
Astana Hub is to assist start-ups in marketing their products to the wider Asia and Pacific region.   
The state program aims to raise the country’s rank in the Innovation Capacity Index from 87th in 
2018 to 63rd by 2022 and attract T123 billion (about $360 million) in start-up funding from 2019 
to 2022. The ICT ecosystem is in its infancy and will strongly benefit from ADB support. 
 
7.  Digital ICT in Kazakhstan has a strong potential to raise productivity and lower the cost of 
production while promoting environment-friendly development and creating jobs. Key constraints 
are (i) significant underinvestment by the government and the private sector in new technologies, 
and (ii) limited local government capacity to promote high-level technologies. ADB can play an 
important role in capacity building and promoting the adoption of high-level technologies in the 
country.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impacts and Outcome 
 
8.  The knowledge and support TA will complement Kazakhstan’s goal of improving its 
citizens’ quality of life and promoting sustainable economic growth through improved uptake of 
digital technologies. The TA is aligned with the following impacts: (i) pace of the country’s 
economic development accelerated, and (ii) peoples’ quality of life improved (footnote 1). The TA 
will have the following outcome: innovative high-level technologies promoted.7 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output  1:  Identifying  opportunities  and  obstacles  to  adopting  selected  digital 
technology solutions. Under this output, the executing and implementing agencies will provide 
ADB with a list of high-level technologies that it is considering promoting. ADB will consider the 
potential development impacts of the items on the list and provide feedback on the opportunities 
and risks associated with each technology. ADB will support the introduction of advanced and 
comprehensive analytical tools such as value for money and total cost of ownership analyses.  
 
10.  Output  2:  Capacity  of  local  government  stakeholders  to  promote  high-level 
technologies improved. The TA project will support capacity development of  government 
agencies in effectively promoting application of digital technologies. The TA project will also 
facilitate transfer of knowledge and partnerships between local agencies and global centers of 
excellence, particularly in partnership with agencies from the Republic of Korea. To ensure the 
sustainability of its capacity-building efforts, ADB will provide support to Astana Hub and other 
institutions dedicated to improving uptake of high-level technologies in Kazakhstan. The TA 
project will promote awareness of the opportunities and risks of digital technologies (to be 
 
7  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
identified under output 1) among stakeholders. The findings of the ADB March 2019 scoping 
mission suggest that there is merit in ADB focusing its support on social innovation start-ups.8 
 
11.  Output 3: Feasibility of digital technology solutions in select areas for sustainable 
development analyzed. The ADB March and October 2019 scoping missions identified possible 
interventions to assist Kazakhstan with identifying and applying digital technologies to support the 
development of (i) smart cities and (ii) smart grid and smart metering.9 Under this output, ADB 
along with the executing and implementing agencies will undertake feasibilities studies of the 
identified technologies. The studies may result in future ADB grant- or loan-financed projects, 
provided such projects satisfy ADB investment criteria. ADB will disseminate lessons and best 
practices emanating from the feasibility studies through capacity-development activities under 
output 2 and other means. The feasibility studies will focus on the following: 
 
(i)  Smart cities program of Kazakhstan. The government has developed a smart city 
concept for the country’s five largest cities. The TA project will focus on one or two 
smart city action areas, such as smart transportation integrating ride-sharing into the 
public transport system. ADB will support developing either individual integrated smart 
planning systems for the five cities in line with its regional Promoting Smart Systems 
in  ADB's  Future  Cities  Program,10 or  digital  infrastructure  such  as  digital  IDs, 
geographic  information  system-enabled  platforms,  and/or  integrated 
payment infrastructure. 
 
(ii)  Smart grid and smart metering. Kazakhstan lacks capacity to manage nationwide 
energy demand and supply (for instance, through variable tariffs). The TA project will 
conduct a feasibility study on introducing a smart grid system to monitor and control 
energy transmission and distribution networks more efficiently. Smart grid systems 
entail  linking  the  national  transmission  grid  with  a  sophisticated  national  energy 
information system. In addition, the TA project will assess the benefits of installing 
smart meters—meters integrated with the national energy grid—at the household level. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000 which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund and administered by ADB. The key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The MDDIAI will be the executing agency of the TA project, while government line 
ministries and agencies will be the implementing agencies, depending on the areas and sectors 
of the feasibility studies.11 ADB’s Kazakhstan Resident Mission will administer the TA. The Digital 
Technology for Development Unit of ADB’s Sustainable Development and Climate Change 
Department  will  support  all  TA  project  activities.  ADB  will  select,  supervise,  and  evaluate 
 
8  Consultations were undertaken in Nur-Sultan during 13–15 March and 9–11 October 2019. Copies of the reports are 
available upon request from ADB’s Kazakhstan Resident Mission. 
9  The MDDIAI sent a letter to ADB on 14 November 2019 confirming its intention to focus on smart cities and smart 
grid technology. 
10 ADB. 2016. Promoting Smart Systems in ADB's Future Cities Program. Manila. 
11 During the consultations held in March and October 2019, the MDDIAI demonstrated an interest in taking part in the 
TA project. A corresponding letter requesting TA was received by ADB’s Kazakhstan Resident Mission from MDDIAI 
in August 2019.

4 
consultants, organize consultation workshops and training, and provide staff to act as resource 
persons as required. The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements

Executing agency  Ministry of Digital Development, Innovations and Aerospace Industry 
Implementing agency  Government line ministries and agencies, depending on focus areas 
of feasibility studies and activities

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
14.  Consulting services. The TA will provide 35 person-months of international consultants 
and 30 person-months of national consultants who will be engaged individually or through firms 
as and when needed. An output-based lump sum contracting approach will be preferred to 
minimize the administrative burden. The consultants will work across feasibility studies to share 
knowledge and experience when appropriate. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB 
Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  its  associated  project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions.12 ADB staff can be used as sector, thematic, 
or technical experts as well as resource persons: their travel-related expenses can be paid 
through the TA. The estimated cost and requisite fields of expertise are indicative, and estimates 
will be finalized prior to approval of each TA feasibility study in consultation with the government 
during follow-up missions. 
 
IV.THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development Bank administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 
to the Government of Kazakhstan to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia 
and  Knowledge  Partnership  Fund  for  Promoting  Digital  Technologies  for  Sustainable 
Development, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
12 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

6  Appendix 1 
Key Activities with Milestones 
Output 1: Identifying opportunities and obstacles to adopting selected digital technology 
solutions 
1.1 Prepare terms of reference to hire consultants for identifying the technological opportunities and 
obstacles (Q1 2020). 
1.2 Consultants identifying technological opportunities and obstacles according to executing and 
implementing agencies’ requests (Q2 2020). 
1.3 Conduct research and discussions by engaging local players (Q3–Q4 2020). 
1.4 Present the results of technological opportunities and obstacles with inventory of solutions to MDDIAI 
and implementing agencies (Q1 2021). 
 
Output 2: Capacity of local government stakeholders to promote high-level technologies improved 
2.1 Identify in close collaboration with local government stakeholders areas for regulatory, institutional, 
and technical support (Q2 2020). 
2.2 Prepare terms of reference to hire consultants for capacity building (Q3 2020). 
2.3 Field consultants to conduct capacity building and training (Q3–Q4 2020). 
2.4 Assess capacity-building results and propose recommendations (Q1 2021). 
 
Output 3: Feasibility of digital technology solutions in select areas for sustainable development 
analyzed  
1.1 In close collaboration with the MDDIAI and implementing agencies, identify scope of feasibility studies 
(Q1 2020). 
1.2 Prepare terms of reference to hire consultants to carry out the feasibility studies (Q2 2020). 
1.3 Field consultants to conduct the feasibility studies (Q3 2020). 
1.4 Prepare a report based on the results of the feasibility studies (Q1 2021). 
1.5 Formulate policy recommendations to the MDDIAI based on the results of the feasibility studies (Q2 
2021). 
1.6 Discuss with the MDDIAI and with stakeholders further collaboration on applying high-level 
technologies in Kazakhstan (Q2 2021).
